description: From early modern French fascher (now fâcher), from Latin fastus (“disdain”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland, Tyneside, Northern England) A worry; trouble; bother.

verbs.description: fash (third-person singular simple present fashes, present participle fashing or fashin, simple past and past participle fashed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scotland, Tyneside, Northern England) To worry; to bother, annoy.
(intransitive, Scotland, Tyneside, Northern England) To trouble oneself; to take pains.
(slang, especially UK) A fascist, a member of the far-right.
examples: The Butchers Here is an old Munich policeman — Wilhelm Frick with eyes like those of a fash.

entries.meaning: (slang, in the plural, especially UK) The far-right, especially violent far-right demonstrators, collectively.
examples: Used to go down to London on bash-the-fash awaydays; turn up at National Front marches and give them a toeing.
